products: Infection Control Antimicrobial Use and Resistance Reporting

access.description: The registered URL returns a clean static HTML page (8.7 KB) with two prominent links: an online browsable index of all EHI tables and a ZIP download of the same content. No redirects, no JavaScript rendering required, no anti-bot protection, no accordion navigation. The ZIP downloads directly with a standard User-Agent header. The online tech spec redirects once (302) from /EHITables/TechSpec to /EHITables/GetTable/_index.htm. This is the gold standard for EHI documentation accessibility.

product_context.description: Epic Systems Corporation is the largest EHR vendor in the United States, serving over 250 million patient records across thousands of health systems. The certified modules (EpicCare Ambulatory Base, EpicCare Inpatient Base, Beacon, Beaker, Infection Control) are components of the broader Epic EHR platform, which includes comprehensive clinical documentation (ambulatory and inpatient), patient portal messaging (MyChart), professional and hospital billing (Resolute), appointment scheduling (Cadence), laboratory (Beaker), radiology (Radiant), oncology (Beacon), surgery (OpTime), behavioral health (Wisdom), population health (Healthy Planet), and payer/insurance management (Tapestry). All modules share a common database, which is what the EHI export dumps. The export documentation covers tables from across all modules, not just the certified components.
product_context.certified_module_name: EpicCare Ambulatory Base / EpicCare Inpatient Base / Beacon / Beaker / Infection Control

export_approach.description: Epic's EHI export is a native database dump of their internal Clarity/Caboodle reporting database tables in tab-separated value (TSV) format. This is the gold standard approach for EHI export: the database inherently contains everything the system stores, and the export is a direct dump of those tables. The documentation describes 7,672 individual database tables with a total of 63,121 columns across all tables. Rich text documents, images, and other non-tabular content are referenced from the TSV tables but exported as separate files in a companion download. The export is described as a 'manual one-time export of health data for one or more patients' — it is patient-scoped and health-system-initiated. Epic notes that actual content varies by health system based on which Epic applications are in use, software version, documentation practices, and configuration.

documentation_quality.description: Epic's EHI documentation is exceptionally detailed. Each of the 7,672 tables has its own HTML page documenting: a natural-language description of the table's purpose, the primary key column(s), and every column with its name, data type (VARCHAR, NUMERIC, DATETIME, INTEGER), discontinued status, and a natural-language description of what it stores. Column descriptions often reference relationships to other tables implicitly (e.g., 'The unique ID assigned to the patient record') though explicit foreign key declarations are not present. No sample data or value set enumerations are provided. The documentation is generated from Epic's internal metadata (filename prefix 'DocGen' suggests automated generation) and dated February 12, 2026, indicating active maintenance. At 63,121 total columns with individual descriptions, this is among the most thorough EHI documentation of any vendor.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: Epic's EHI export is the most comprehensive of any EHR vendor, covering virtually all categories of electronic health information. With 7,672 tables and 63,121 columns dumped directly from the native database, this is a true database-level export that captures everything the system stores. Clinical data is exhaustively covered across ambulatory, inpatient, lab, radiology, oncology, and specialty modules. Secure messaging is well-represented with 82 MyChart tables (MYC_CONVO, MYC_CONVO_MSGS) and 19 Chat tables. Billing is deeply covered with 382 AP_CLAIM tables, 51 ARPB (professional billing) tables, and 114 HSP_ACCT (hospital account) tables. Insurance/coverage has 36 COVERAGE tables plus authorization and benefits tables. Scheduling is covered through PAT_ENC (115 tables covering all encounters including appointments) and APPT tables. Documents and images are represented through DOCS_RCVD tables and DICOM tables. Audit trails are extensively present with 157 tables containing 'AUDIT' in their name plus numerous _HX (history) tables. This is the gold standard for EHI export completeness.

clinical.evidence: Exhaustive clinical coverage. Key tables include: ALLERGY (19 cols), CLARITY_MEDICATION, CLARITY_IMMUNZATN, PAT_ENC (115 related tables, 72+ cols on the main table), ORDER tables (241 tables), IP_FLWSHT (flowsheet/vitals), HNO (clinical notes, 16 tables), DIAGNOSIS tables, PROBLEM_LIST tables, LAB tables, DENTAL tables, surgical tables (OR_CASE), oncology tables (BEACON), and hundreds more. Every clinical domain in a comprehensive EHR is represented.

secure_messages.evidence: Strong messaging coverage. 82 MYC_ (MyChart) tables including MYC_CONVO ('MyChart conversations'), MYC_CONVO_MSGS ('MyChart Conversation viewable messages'), MYC_CONVO_USERS, MYC_CONVO_VIEWERS, MYC_CONVO_FUTURE_MSGS, and conversation-about tables for accounts, claims, coverages, medications, medical advice, referrals, and results. Additionally 19 CHAT_ tables (CHAT_MESSAGE, CHAT_MESSAGE_CONTENT, CHAT_CONVERSATIONS, CHAT_PARTICIPANT), CAL_MESSAGE tables (CAL_MESSAGE_BODY, CAL_MESSAGE_TO, CAL_MESSAGE_CC, CAL_MESSAGE_BCC), and ENC_LETTERS. Both patient-facing (MyChart) and internal messaging/chat are covered.

billing_financial.evidence: Deeply comprehensive billing coverage. 382 AP_CLAIM tables covering claims, claim attachments, claim adjustments, claim diagnoses, claim procedures, and claim letters. 51 ARPB (Accounts Receivable Professional Billing) tables including ARPB_TRANSACTIONS ('professional billing transactions' with 67 columns including transaction dates, amounts, and classifications). 114 HSP_ACCT (Hospital Account) tables. 13 ACCOUNT tables for guarantor accounts ('current professional billing and hospital billing balances'). BILL_SCHED_PMT tables for scheduled payments. ACCUM_* tables for accumulated claim and service information.

insurance_coverage.evidence: 36 COVERAGE tables including COVERAGE ('high-level information on both managed care and indemnity coverage records'), ACCT_COVERAGE. AUTHORIZATIONS and AUTHORIZATIONS_2 tables. BENEFITS and BENEFITS_TEMPLATE tables. BENEFIT_EVALUATOR, BENEFIT_SVC_TYPE, BENEFIT_VARIABLE. REFERRAL tables (65 total). ELIGIBILITY tables. CAP_PAY (capitation payment) tables. ABN_PLAN_INFO (Advance Beneficiary Notice plan info).

appointments_scheduling.evidence: PAT_ENC is the primary encounter table ('contains all appointments, office visits, telephone encounters, and other types of encounters') with 115 related tables and 72+ columns. APPT tables (APPT_REQUEST, APPT_CSN_COUNTS, APPT_SELF_CHECKIN_INFO, APPT_LETTER_RECIPIENTS). Visit-related tables across billing contexts (ARPB_VISITS, BEN_VISIT_NOTES). OR_CASE tables for surgical scheduling. EOW_APPOINTMENT_REQUESTS.

documents_images.evidence: DOCS_RCVD ('High level information about received documents') with related tables for encounters, diagnoses, fax numbers, and MyChart messages. 12 DICOM tables (DICOM_MANIFEST, DICOM_MANIFEST_INSTANCE, DICOM_MANIFEST_SERIES, DICOM_SLICE_INFO, DICOM_IMAGE_WINDOW_INFO). Document-related tables: DOCUMENT_SIG_DATA, DOCUMENT_SMARTFORM_LIST, DOCUMENT_STAMPS. Attachment tables: AP_CLAIM_ATTACHMENTS, CLM_ATTACH, CLP_ATTACHMENTS, APPEAL_GRV_REQ_ATTACHMENT, EPA_ATTACHMENT_NOTES. EMBRYOLOGY_DOCUMENTS, DOC_INFO_CE_SCANS, DOC_INFO_DICOM. FINDING_IMAGES_METADATA. Epic notes that rich text documents and images are exported as separate files alongside the TSV tables.

audit_trails.evidence: 157 tables with 'AUDIT' in their name including: ANTICOAG_AUDIT, AN_DELETION_AUDIT, AN_HSB_LINK_AUDIT, AN_STAFF_AUDIT, APPEAL_GRV_AUDIT_TRAIL, APPT_DECL_DATES_AUDIT, CUST_SVC_MYC_LETTER_AUDIT, MYC_CONVO_EXPORT_AUDIT, and many more. Extensive _HX (history) tables throughout: ACCOUNT_VIS_ACT_HX, ADDR_HX, ACCT_COLL_AGENCY_HX, ADV_EVT_GRADE_HISTORY, AI_SESSION_HX, ALT_HISTORY, CHAT_ACCESS_LOG, CHAT_ACTION_LOG. Edit trails: ENC_DX_EDIT_TRAIL. These cover both clinical and administrative audit trails.

issues: Epic notes that export content varies by health system based on which applications are in use, software version, documentation practices, and configuration, meaning the 7,672-table schema represents a superset — any given health system's export may include fewer tables.

While relationships between tables are implicitly described in column descriptions, there are no explicit foreign key declarations, which could make it challenging to reconstruct complex data relationships without Epic domain expertise.
Value sets and code enumerations are not documented — a consumer would need to infer meaning from the data values themselves or have access to Epic's reference data.
No sample data is provided, making it harder to understand the practical structure of the TSV output without an actual export to reference.

downloaded_files.description: Complete EHI Export schema documentation containing 7,674 files: 1 CSS stylesheet, 1 HTML index page, and 7,672 individual HTML table documentation files. Each file documents a single database table with description, primary key, and column-level detail (name, type, discontinued status, description). Uncompressed size: 83,024,535 bytes. Generated 2/12/2026.

summary: Epic's EHI export is the gold standard for ONC b(10) compliance. It is a native database dump of 7,672 tables (63,121 total columns) in TSV format, covering all seven EHI categories comprehensively: clinical data across all specialties, MyChart patient portal messaging (82 tables), deep billing/claims (382+ claim tables, 51 professional billing tables), insurance/coverage/authorizations, scheduling/encounters (115 PAT_ENC tables), documents/images (including DICOM), and extensive audit trails (157+ audit tables). The documentation is publicly accessible, well-organized, auto-generated from metadata, and actively maintained (last updated February 2026). The only gaps are the absence of explicit foreign key documentation, value set definitions, and sample data.
notes: Epic's approach of dumping native database tables is fundamentally different from vendors who export FHIR resources or C-CDA documents. Because the export comes directly from Epic's Clarity/Caboodle reporting database, it inherently captures everything the system stores — there is no translation layer where data could be lost. The 7,672-table count is not inflated; these are real database tables with meaningful column-level documentation. The 'DocGen' prefix on the extraction directory suggests this documentation is automatically generated from Epic's internal metadata system, which explains both its comprehensiveness and its consistency. The February 2026 date indicates Epic regenerates this documentation with each software release.
